I.  THE ONGOING PROJECT 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Microfinance Risk Participation and Guarantee 
Program (MFP) is a credit-enhancement initiative designed to address market gaps by sharing 
risks to facilitate local currency lending to low-income people, predominantly women. With a 
program limit of $340 million that is operationalized on a revolving basis, the MFP has supported 
$1.15 billion in new local currency loans since its inception, benefiting almost 6 million borrowers, 
mostly women, across ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs). 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The peri-urban and urban poor often reside in densely populated settlements, bearing the 
brunt of poor housing conditions that are highly vulnerable to climate change-induced extreme 
weather  events.1 This  situation  is  compounded  by  deteriorating  access  to  basic  services, 
especially water and sanitation.2 Furthermore, given the geographical locations and their lower 
level of economic activity and prosperity, resources and institutional capacities in these locations 
are often limited. In many instances, interventions made by the government are inadequate and 
affordable commercial solutions are rare. There is an opportunity to build the resilience of 
households by funding home improvements and improved access to water and sanitation services 
through affordable, commercially structured solutions. In Bangladesh, for example, the estimated 
annual demand for urban housing microfinance is BDT 17.27 billion ($0.22 billion).3  The capital 
required for home improvements and safe water and sewage connections is typically provided by 
microfinance  institutions  (MFIs)  via  group-based  lending.  Collective  decision-making  within 
neighborhoods also helps build resilience in the urban communities. 
 
3.  A  critical  condition  for  financing  home  improvements  is  an  existing  well-functioning 
microfinance channel. MFIs are usually well-placed to cover the targeted population. While 
wholesale banks have the resources to support these activities, constraints at both the partner 
financial  institution  (PFI)4 and  MFI  levels  impede  these  entities  from  contributing  to  more 
significant outcomes. These constraints relate to: (i) PFIs’ inability to assess and review the risks 
associated with long-term loans; and (ii) MFIs’ limited technical and operational capacities to 
structure appropriate loan products, work with the micro-borrowers to budget the capital outlay, 
and oversee the design, material-sourcing, and construction activities. There is also significant 
risk aversion at both the PFI and MFI operating levels in the absence of technical support and 
systematic hand-holding from the loan product design to the demand assessment and market 
mapping, and the final scaling-up stage. 
 
4.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) will help the MFP continue to address market 
gaps while strengthening financing for upgrading housing and access to water supply and 
sanitation  through  the  provision  of  loan  loss  guarantees  targeting  these  micro-home

2 
improvements loans. The TA will target disaster-prone peri-urban settlements in Bangladesh, 
Indonesia, Myanmar, Nepal, the Philippines, and Vietnam. The TA will also provide MFP with 
funds to conduct institutional strengthening of participating MFIs that will include knowledge 
dissemination, beneficiary training, formulation of enabling policies, and progress monitoring. The 
proposed TA addresses bottlenecks by providing first-loss guarantees on loans that PFIs extend 
to MFIs specifically targeted at these micro-home improvements and by engaging reputable 
technical partners to work with MFIs to build their skills for delivering such loans to target 
beneficiaries. 
 
5.  Component 1. First Loss Guarantee. The first loss guarantee funded by the TA will 
cover up to 10% of the principal of eligible loans provided by PFIs to qualified MFIs for specific 
purposes. The remaining 90% of the loan (the senior risk) will be shared equally between the PFI 
and the ADB MFP. The first loss guarantee will build on the MFP platform, which has already 
established  significant  outreach  to  PFIs  and  MFIs  in  the  target  countries.  With  this 
complementarity, the first loss guarantee is expected to rapidly generate significant leverage by 
expanding the PFIs’ risk tolerance towards longer-term financing to MFIs. This will also incentivize 
MFIs to provide affordable longer tenor micro-housing loans to the targeted households5 and 
improve the asset-liability management of the MFIs. 
 
6.  Component 2. Institutional Strengthening of MFIs. The TA will also provide capacity 
building to MFIs covering: (i) product development, market-scoping and project planning; (ii) 
training of MFI staff; (iii) establishing guidelines for climate-resilient model housing and materials; 
and (iv) creating local language content knowledge-dissemination and training materials. The 
successful delivery of the long-term micro housing loans requires an MFI to structure appropriate 
lending products and improve its interface with the beneficiaries by covering the capital outlay 
and technical design, material-sourcing, construction of the home unit and water and sanitation 
facilities within realistic debt service targets.  
 
7.  ADB will engage the consulting services of an experienced consulting firm (technical 
partners to provide technical advice for participating MFIs). Qualified organizations include but 
are not limited to the following organizations: World Habitat, Build Change, Habitat for Humanity, 
International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, SKAT Consulting Ltd., and 
Gawad Kalinga. Required expertise includes detailed market mapping, loan product design, roll-
out of appropriate policies, training of MFI loan officers in budgeting, development of standardized 
local language content for micro-housing activities, and project monitoring and evaluation to 
complement the outreach of selected qualified MFIs. ADB will also explore the possibility of 
obtaining cofinancing through a challenge selection process of technical partners.  
 
8.  The TA is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2030 supporting three of its operational priorities. 
The first loss guarantee component addresses poverty reduction. The TA creates an enabling 
environment for microfinance to promote access to finance for the poor and foster inclusive 
growth. In the area of gender equality, the TA incorporates guiding principles for MFIs to be 
supportive  of  women  inclusion  and  protection.  Integrating  climate  change  adaptation  in 
microfinance  demonstrates  focus  on  building  climate  and  disaster  reliance  and  enhancing 
environmental sustainability. 
 
 
5  While the housing assets do only generate cash inflows via borrower cost savings over the medium-term, longer 
maturity loans (ranging from 24-26 months) are required to meet the borrowers’ debt service capacity.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $3,000,000 and will be financed on a grant basis by the Urban 
Climate Change Resilience Trust Fund (UCCRTF)under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility 
 
(UFPF) and administered by ADB. At the completion date of the TA, any unutilized portion of the 
first loss cover will be used to establish a fund6 for providing: (i) first-loss cover for micro-

DFID, for this arrangement. As the first loss guarantee is a contingent claim and there is no certainty that ADB will 
need to pay out under the obligation, the unutilized funds will be re-deployed in these specified end-uses; on a 
revolving basis. In order to have proper tracking, reporting, and end-usage control and oversight, these funds will be 
set aside in the Catalytic Fund, which will be maintained by ADB.

outreach and capacity building from the non-utilized (and the post-default recovery) portion of the 
TA. Also, MFP will explore the possibility of co-financing from the selected technical provider. The 
key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.

Financial Institutions Division (PSFI), will procure, supervise and evaluate consultants. The

12.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time)7 and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions. Individual consultants will be recruited to provide international and 
national consulting inputs. A firm with expertise on climate change resilient house improvement, 
water and sanitation will be engaged. Resource persons will also be engaged for trainings and 
seminars. 
 
13.  Reporting. ADB will submit to UCCRTF semi-annual progress reports on activities, 
disbursements, and the inception, interim, final and completion report of the project.

III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  administering  a  portion  of  TA  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$3,000,000  to  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  for  Building  Community  Resilience  through 
Microfinance in Lagging Peri-Urban Settlements, and hereby reports this to the Board.
